text: thank you much very much for coming here I do apologize for those of you who saw
that the title of the talk was slow search and thought oh good I have to go there because Jamie's going to tell me about how to make search faster because
as Michael mentioned I'm not here to actually get rid of slow search I'm here to advocate on behalf of it so in the 20
years that I've been trying to study and understand and support search slow and search are never used together in a
positive way and I but really a lot of
the things that kind of what I've been looking at as I study how people interact with external information
resources to find things has shown that search is a really fascinating rich and
complex process so for example your two
or three word query that you typically give to a search engine isn't nearly enough to express what most information
needs maybe if you're looking for facebook it's enough but if you want to understand a medical condition or if you want to plan a vacation it's just too
little so I started out thinking a fair amount about how we can use context to
understand what people are looking for when when they give a short two or three word query and that led to a whole area
of research within personalized search I actually developed the first algorithm that being uses to personalized search
results but what became evident as we were doing that is that are much more
than just an individual query in search results people are thinking a lot more about large complex tasks and that's
where slow search comes in trying to think about how to support these more complex tasks slow search builds on a
series of slow movements some of you are probably familiar with a slow food movement that advocates for taking more
time to prepare and enjoy food so that you connect more with what you're consuming but there's actually other
slow movements that I think are pretty fun too one is a slow parenting movement
and the idea behind the slow parenting movement is that we're not trying to raise our children just to be grown-ups
as fast as possible but instead we should step back and think a little bit about you know
just capturing and enjoying childhood for what it is and not for where you're going and I talk about slow parenting
partly as an excuse to show me for cute boys another slow movement that I think
it's pretty interesting it's a slow science movement many of us are probably familiar with the pressure to sort of
you know publish soon or meet the next deadline slow science advocates that advocates say we should be thinking more
about what what's going to impact the world five years or ten years or even longer down the line even if that comes
at the expense of short-term productivity as a slow search builds on
the ideas behind these various slow movements and there's a handful of ways that you could imagine including time
into the search process one is to help the searcher slow down and think a little bit about what they're doing as
they as they search so maybe you learn as you're searching maybe you encounter serendipitous information as you're
searching and I'm going to touch on that a little bit but I'm actually going to focus on a second aspect of slow search
in this talk today and that's thinking about algorithmically what might we do
if we had more time to produce search results for people because search
engines haven't ever really done this instead what search engines do it's are focused on getting search results to
people as fast as humanly possible and there's a really good reason for that a
study after study has shown that when people get search results just a little
bit slower they think that they're a lot worse so both both our research at Bing
and research that's been done at Google has shown that if you slow search results by even just a couple hundred
milliseconds you're going to decrease the experience that people have so the way that we run these experiments is
we'll take a query that you've issued and normally when a search engine gets a query it faces as fast as it can to
throw the search results back out at people in these experiments what we did instead is we get your query and then we
hold on to it for a fraction of a second we might hold on to your query for 100 milliseconds or 200 milliseconds and
then we'll give you your search results the same search results that we would give you we didn't hold to it and even though people can't
actually notice a couple hundred milliseconds it's basically imperceptible to people when we do that
that people with their search results will go and interact less with the search results they click fewer results
they abandon their query more the issue you are queries and those changes
actually persist over time so we see that even if we stop holding onto your
search results by a couple hundred milliseconds next week you're searching less so there's this real strong
incentive to getting people results as fast as possible and search engines invest a ton of resources and a ton of
effort and a ton of time into doing that one examples we assume term independence
so that we don't have to think of all of the different possible ways that content relates to each other we also do a lot
of invest a lot in caching there's even some more obvious changes that you might
have seen how many people know that Google changed their logo recently yeah do you like the new logo better yeah
it's ugly right you know what's good about it it's made entirely out of vectors it loads really fast a lot
smaller than the old logo and so their search result page will load that much faster even you know 50 milliseconds
faster and your experience searching you'll think that Google actually has better search results even changes that
are designed it seems sort of unambiguously good end up being bad if they slow down your search experience so
another example this is another one by Google is they actually ran this experiment where they decided to give
people 20 search results instead of 10 search results in response to a query and this makes kind of logical sense
when you think about the fact that nobody ever clicks on the second search result page nobody ever ever ever clicks
on the like next search result page and you know that's a shame because when you look at the relevance of search results
the first couple search results tends to be like those results rank one or two are very likely to be relevant but by
the time you're getting to like the fifth result it's still likely to be relevant but the fifth result in the
15th results are about the same likeliness of being relevant so there's lots of good relevant content on that
second page that you don't ever see because you're not clicking on that next search result page so Google figured okay we'll give you 20
results instead of 10 there's no way that we're going to be harming anything there and yet when they did that all of

a synchronous there's no way that I would expect to say hey friends where should I eat in palo alto tonight and

we just call it mobile search because you know going over the cellular tower
to get information is really slow it takes a longer time and we actually see different search behavior from mobile

and it's actually kind of I used to give this as a crazy example this may be
becoming a little bit more realistic but when you think of searching from outer space there's inherent limitations into
how fast information can travel so when Elon Musk puts people on Mars and those
Martians want to search Earth databases it's going to take 25 minutes for the light to travel from Mars to earth and

of course if you're going to take extra time whether it's an extra five minutes because the query is coming from Mars or

a rough in a really rough overview of thinking about the search process there's four there's three steps one you

its scale which means they're really good at retrieving content taking some
of representation and matching it to a large corpus of other representations
that's something that we can't do be a pain in the butt if I asked you to go search 1,000,000,000 1,000,000,000,000

people with the answer your questions sometimes have the answer written in a different way than how you express your
information need and if we can expand the query to more closely match the documents an answer then we can do a
good job so just kind of go through this quickly but we just we tried having people do query expansion is and then

search engines are already doing this algorithmically this is just having people go get involved and we ran this

found that query expansion is generally ineffective and this is because what
you're trying to do when you're solving the vocabulary mismatch problem is not more accurately describe the person's
